Literature Review: The reaction-diffusion (RD) framework, first proposed by Alan Turing in 1952, has been a cornerstone of morphogenesis research for decades. Despite its widespread application, the RD approach has faced criticism and skepticism in the field of developmental biology. This literature review aims to summarize the key aspects of Turing's work, discuss the advantages of phenomenological RD models in understanding skin color patterning, and explore the utility of linear stability analysis and numerical simulations in demonstrating the emergence of deterministic RD from chaotic microscopic agents.
